subject: Chemistry (CSS – Pure & Applied) — Acid–Base, Thermodynamics, Coordination, Kinetics, Organic, Quantum, Industrial, Spectroscopy

notes.title: Acid–Base Theories (Arrhenius, Brønsted–Lowry, Lewis) + HSAB
notes.content: Compare Arrhenius (H+ in water), Brønsted–Lowry (proton donor/acceptor), and Lewis (electron-pair acceptor/donor). Use HSAB to rationalize stability and rates; classify acids/bases and predict complex formation.
keyTakeaways: Lewis is most general; encompasses non-protic acid–base behavior.
HSAB: hard–hard and soft–soft interactions favored.
Strength trends: structure, charge, electronegativity, solvation.

notes.title: Buffers & Henderson–Hasselbalch
notes.content: Define buffers, derive Henderson–Hasselbalch from Ka expression, design buffers with target pH, and calculate pH change upon addition of acid/base.
keyTakeaways: Best buffer when pH ≈ pKa and [acid] ≈ [base].
Capacity ∝ total buffer concentration.
Use log ratio to tune pH.

resources.title: LibreTexts — Calculating pH of Buffer Solutions

notes.title: Langmuir Adsorption Isotherm (Derivation, Assumptions, Limits)
notes.content: State surface site assumptions (monolayer, identical sites, no interactions). Derive θ = (K P)/(1 + K P) and linear forms (1/q vs 1/C). Contrast with Freundlich; discuss catalytic relevance.
keyTakeaways: Monolayer coverage → saturation at high P/C.
Linearized plots enable KL and qmax extraction.
Fails for multilayer or interacting adsorbates.

notes.title: Acid–Base Catalysis (Specific vs General; Mechanistic Ideas)
notes.content: Differentiate specific (H3O+/OH− only) vs general acid/base catalysis (any HA/B). Connect to reaction coordinate; illustrate with ester hydrolysis and imine formation.
keyTakeaways: Catalyst participates and is regenerated.
Rate depends on buffer components in general catalysis.
Proton transfers change LFERs and activation barriers.

notes.title: Phase Rule (Gibbs) & Applications
notes.content: Use F = C − P + 2 (or +1 for condensed). Apply to water and sulfur systems; identify degrees of freedom, invariant points, and phase diagrams.
keyTakeaways: Counting components and phases is key.
At triple point of one-component: F = 0.
Use for buffer capacity in two-component systems.

notes.title: Clausius–Clapeyron Equation
notes.content: Derive ln(P2/P1) = −ΔHvap/R (1/T2 − 1/T1). Use to estimate vapor pressures and boiling points; state assumptions (ΔHvap≈const, ideal behavior).
keyTakeaways: Linear ln P vs 1/T with slope −ΔHvap/R.
Good for phase boundary extrapolation.
Deviations from non-ideality and T-dependent ΔHvap.

notes.title: Free Energy & Equilibrium (ΔG°, K, and Temperature)
notes.content: Relate ΔG° = −RT ln K; discuss temperature dependence via van 't Hoff; connect spontaneity (ΔG sign) to Le Châtelier.
keyTakeaways: K = e^(−ΔG°/RT) links thermodynamics to composition.
Sign of ΔH° sets d(ln K)/dT.
Use activities for accuracy (non-ideal solutions).

notes.title: Arrhenius Equation & Temperature Dependence of Rates
notes.content: k = A e^(−Ea/RT); extract Ea from ln k vs 1/T. Compare to modified Arrhenius; link to collision and transition-state pictures.
keyTakeaways: Slope = −Ea/R on Arrhenius plot.
A reflects frequency/orientation factors.
Catalysts lower Ea (change pathway).

notes.title: Transition-State Theory (Eyring)
notes.content: Rate ∝ concentration of activated complex × transmission; compare with Arrhenius and derive Eyring equation. Enzyme catalysis context.
keyTakeaways: Barrier crossing controls rate.
Provides enthalpy/entropy of activation.
Explains temperature/rate trends beyond simple collision theory.

resources.title: LibreTexts — Transition State Theory (Millersville P. Chem I)

notes.title: Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution (Mechanism + Key Reactions)
notes.content: Two-step mechanism via σ-complex; rate-determining loss of aromaticity then deprotonation; directing effects; nitration, halogenation, sulfonation, Friedel–Crafts.
keyTakeaways: EDG → ortho/para; EWG (esp. —NO2, —CF3) → meta.
Carbocation stabilization explains reactivity/order.
Catalysts (Lewis/Brønsted acids) activate electrophiles.

notes.title: Grignard Reagents — Synthesis & Applications
notes.content: RMgX formation, Schlenk equilibrium, additions to carbonyls (alcohols), CO2 (acids), epoxides; incompatibilities (protic media).
keyTakeaways: Air/moisture sensitive; use dry ether.
Carbonyl additions governed by sterics/chemospecificity.
Useful for homologation and C–C bond formation.

notes.title: Crystal Field Theory: Splitting, Color, Magnetism; Jahn–Teller
notes.content: Explain Δo/Δt splitting, spectrochemical series idea, d–d transitions and spin states; introduce Jahn–Teller distortions in degenerate configurations (e.g., d9).
keyTakeaways: Ligand field splits d orbitals → color and magnetism.
Weak/strong field affects pairing/spin (high vs low).
Jahn–Teller: distortion removes degeneracy and lowers energy.

notes.title: Quantum Basics: de Broglie, Schrödinger; Particle in a Box
notes.content: State de Broglie λ=h/p, set up boundary conditions for 1D/3D box, energy quantization En ∝ n², node structure; Born interpretation and operators.
keyTakeaways: Confinement → quantized energy levels.
Wavefunction squares → probability density.
Box length controls spacing (∝1/L²).

resources.title: MIT OCW 5.61 — Lecture 5: Free Particle & 1D Box (PDF)

notes.title: Industrial Chemistry: Sulfuric Acid (Contact Process) & Urea
notes.content: Outline catalysts/conditions and flow for H2SO4 (contact) and urea synthesis; discuss emissions control and process chemistry ties to thermodynamics/kinetics.
keyTakeaways: Optimize via Le Châtelier (pressure/temperature) and catalysts (V2O5).
Industrial steps often balance rate and equilibrium.
Environmental controls integral (SOx/NOx handling).

notes.title: Environmental Chemistry: Acid Rain & Greenhouse Basics (thermo/kinetics links)
notes.content: SOx/NOx chemistry to acids; buffering capacity of soils/waters; link to equilibrium constants and kinetics of atmospheric transformations.
keyTakeaways: Formation pathways depend on radicals and catalysis.
Mitigation: emission cuts and neutralization.
pH, alkalinity, and carbonate equilibria control impact.

notes.title: Spectroscopy Touchpoints for Exams (UV–Vis, IR, NMR cross-links)
notes.content: Electronic transitions (n→π*, π→π*), IR functional group IDs, NMR δ/π-anisotropy trends; tie aromatic substituent effects and conjugation to spectra.
keyTakeaways: Conjugation bathochromically shifts UV–Vis.
IR: carbonyls, OH/NH, fingerprint region patterns.
NMR: shielding/deshielding trends (aryl > vinylic > aldehydic).
